{{Infobox person | name = Suranne Jones | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Sarah Anne Jones | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1978|08|27}} | birth_place = [[Chadderton]], [[Greater Manchester]], [[England]] | death_date = | death_place = | othername = | occupation = Actress | yearsactive = 1997âpresent | spouse = | partner = | website = | bfjaawards = | awards = }} '''Suranne Jones''' (born '''Sarah Anne Jones'''; 27 August 1978)<ref name="College">{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/education/2004/oct/26/furthereducation.uk3?INTCMP=SRCH|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|title=College days|first=Katie|last=Shimmon|date=2004-10-26|accessdate=2011-06-18}}</ref> is an [[English people|English]] actress. She first rose to prominence playing the role of [[Karen McDonald]] in [[ITV1]]'s soap opera ''[[Coronation Street]]'' over a period of four years. In 2004, she left ''Coronation Street'', later remarking: "I just thought, while [Karen]'s brilliant and I'm enjoying her, I've got to get out".<ref name="Independent">{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/no-more-tears-why-suranne-jones-has-plenty-to-smile-about-1880962.html|publisher=''[[The Independent]]''|title=No more tears: Why Suranne Jones has plenty to smile about|first=Gerard|last=Gilbert|date=2010-01-31|accessdate=2011-06-15}}</ref>
Upon leaving, Jones took on roles in many drama series broadcast on ITV1 and [[BBC1]], such as ''[[Vincent (TV series)|Vincent]]'', ''[[Strictly Confidential (TV series)|Strictly Confidential]]'', ''[[Unforgiven (TV series)|Unforgiven]]'', ''[[Five_Days#Series_two|Five Days]]'' and ''[[Single Father (TV series)|Single Father]]'', whilst also appearing in various theatre productions, earning her critical acclaim, described by Andrew Billen of ''[[The Times]]'' as being in a category of "those brave, talented few who earn their wings on a soap and then fly gloriously beyond it".<ref name="Billen"/> In 2011 Jones starred in ''[[Scott & Bailey]]'' as DC Rachel Bailey, with the television series being an original idea conceived by Jones herself and fellow actress [[Sally Lindsay]].
==Early life== Suranne Jones was born Sarah Anne Jones in [[Chadderton]], [[Greater Manchester]],<ref name="advertiser503963">{{cite news |url= http://www.oldhamadvertiser.co.uk/news/s/503963_suranne_prefers_home_to_a_few_good_men|publisher=''[[Oldham Advertiser]]''|title=Suranne prefers home to 'A Few Good Men'|first=Ian|last=Wylie|date=2005-09-14|accessdate=2008-12-21}}</ref> on 27 August 1978,<ref name="College"/> the daughter of Chris and Jenny Jones, an engineer and a secretary, respectively.<ref name="Daily Mail">{{cite news|author=[[Liz Jones]] |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/you/article-1312579/Suranne-Jones-Coronation-Street-icon-Suranne-sets-sights-Broadway.html|publisher=''[[Daily Mail]]''|title=Suranne's brunette ambition: The former Corrie star sets her sights on Broadway|date=2010-09-18|accessdate=2011-06-15}}</ref> She also has a sibling, an older brother named Gary.<ref name="Sue Crawford">{{cite news|author=Sue Crawford |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Interview+Suranne+Jones%3A+Me+get+married%3F+Don't+bet+on+it%3B+Coronation...-a074728738 |publisher=''[[Daily Mirror|The Mirror]]''|title=Interview Suranne Jones: Me get married? Don't bet on it|date=2001-05-19|accessdate=2011-08-27}}</ref> Jones was raised a [[Catholic]]; her priest suggested to her father she be christened Sarah Anne, instead of Suranne, her great-grandmother's name, as Suranne was not "a proper name".<ref name="Herald Scotland"/> Jones grew up in a house surrounded by two farms and their fields and commented that one of her earliest memories is of "cows looking in the window as we ate our tea".<ref name="Herald Scotland"/> As a child she was talkative, and later recounted that her priest would say "I'm praying you can concentrate just a bit more".<ref name="Herald Scotland">{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/a-piece-of-my-mind-suranne-jones-actress-1.836889 |publisher=''[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]]''|title=A PIECE OF MY MIND: Suranne Jones, Actress |first=|last=|date=2008-07-05|accessdate=2011-06-15}}</ref> Jones suffers from carpophobia (fear of wrists), which she believes possibly developed from viewing imagery of [[Christ]]'s crucifixion and [[stigmata]] as a child.<ref name="DS">{{cite news |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/showbiz/news/a110980/ten-things-you-never-knew-about-suranne-jones.html |publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|title=Ten Things You Never Knew About Suranne Jones |first=Beth|last=Hilton|date=2008-07-16|accessdate=2011-06-15}}</ref> Talking of her childhood, Jones commented that "I think I always wanted to be different and felt very stifled at school".<ref name="Herald Scotland"/> Jones also stated, "I was bullied at school and I let that get hold of me and withdrew into myself - I regret letting that happen".<ref name="Guardian">{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/theguardian/2005/sep/24/weekend7.weekend |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|title=Q&A: Suranne Jones, actor |first=Rosanna|last=Greenstreet|date=2005-09-24|accessdate=2011-06-15}}</ref> She became a member of the [[Oldham Theatre Workshop]],<ref name="Oldham Theatre Workshop">{{cite news |url=http://www.citylife.co.uk/news_and_reviews/news/9769_showbiz_secrets_in_safe_hands|publisher=''City Life''|title=Showbiz secrets in safe hands |first=Carmel|last=Thomason|date=2006-02-08|accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref> where she befriended [[Antony Cotton]], who now plays [[Sean Tully]] on ''Coronation Street''.<ref name="Daily Mail"/> She completed a [[BTEC National Diploma]] in Performing Arts, though she felt "that [wasn't] quite the same as drama school".<ref name="Telegraph 2011">{{cite news |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/8707071/Racist-historian-David-Starkey-is-sunk-by-Rastamouse.html|publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]|title=Suranne Jones hits back at 'snobs' |first=Tim|last=Walker|date=2011-08-18|accessdate=2011-08-27}}</ref>
==Career== ===Career beginnings=== Jones began acting professionally aged 16.<ref name="Anna Shepard">{{cite news |url=http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/body_and_soul/article556710.ece?token=null&offset=0&page=1|publisher=''[[The Times]]''|title=Not just anybody: Suranne Jones|first=Anna|last=Shepard|date=2005-08-20|accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref> Andrew Billen of ''[[The Times]]'', while acknowledging her professional career beginnings at 16, noted that "she took to the stage at 8".<ref name="Billen">{{cite news |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article7029214.ece|publisher=''[[The Times]]''|title=What Suranne Jones did next|first=Andrew|last=Billen|date=2010-02-17|accessdate=2011-06-17}}</ref> Jones later recalled that her first role was at the age of 8, in ''[[Wait Until Dark]]'' as Gloria.<ref name="August 2011">{{cite news |url=http://www.metro.co.uk/showbiz/interviews/871515-suranne-jones-i-was-banned-after-saying-penis-on-stage|publisher=''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]''|title=Suranne Jones: I was banned after saying 'penis' on stage|first=Andrew|last=Williams|date=2011-08-05|accessdate=2011-08-11}}</ref> Upon joining the trade union [[Equity (trade union)|Equity]], Jones took on the [[stage name]] 'Suranne', as her birth name was already taken, and union rules dictate that each union member must have a different name.<ref name="Billen"/> Having secured herself an [[Talent agent|agent]] aged 15, she soon after began to act in the theatre.<ref name="Billen"/> Jones' television career began, however, in 1997, where she had a very small role in ''[[Coronation Street]]'' in April 1997 as Mandy Phillips, a girlfriend of Chris Collins. She was then cast in a television advert for [[Maltesers]],<ref name="Sue Crawford"/> guest starred in episodes of series such as ''City Central'' and had a small role in ''My Wonderful Life''. She auditioned for the role of [[Charity Dingle]] on the soap opera ''[[Emmerdale]]'', becoming one of the final four actors considered for the part,<ref name="Sue Crawford"/> though the role was eventually given to [[Emma Atkins]]. She also auditioned for the part of [[Geena Gregory]] on ''Coronation Street'', though she felt she knew [[Jennifer James]] would win the roleâwhich she didâupon seeing her at the auditions.<ref name="Sue Crawford"/>
In 2000, some weeks after her unsuccessful audition for Geena Gregory, she was contacted by ''Coronation Street'' bosses, who offered her a part of a new character.<ref name="Sue Crawford"/> Jones took on the role of Karen Phillips (no relation to Mandy), making her first appearance on 21 June. The character, after marrying [[Steve McDonald (Coronation Street)|Steve McDonald]], took on his surname, and became [[Karen McDonald]]. Described as "a bulldog in hoop earrings"<ref name="Guardian"/> and a "[[Victoria Beckham]] wannabe",<ref name="Independent"/> the role garnered Jones public attention, with episodes involving feuds between her and rival [[Tracy Barlow]] receiving millions of viewers; the episode featuring Karen and Steve's (second) wedding, ruined by Tracy Barlow's revelation that her daughter [[Amy Barlow]] was Steve's love child, received 16.3 million viewers.<ref name="Sun">{{cite news |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/tv/soaps/3271691/Bar-owner-Nick-Tilsley-to-be-probed-over-Corrie-tram-crash.html|publisher=''[[The Sun (newspaper)|The Sun]]''|title=Heat on Nick for Corrie's inferno|first=Lucy|last=Connolly|date=2010-12-11|accessdate=2011-06-15}}</ref> In May 2004 it was announced that she was to leave ''Coronation Street'' in the end of that year after four years of playing Karen. Jones described working on a soap opera as "exhausting",<ref name="Anna Shepard"/> remarking, "I was living and breathing Karen McDonald".<ref name="Anna Shepard"/> Jones made her last appearance as Karen on [[Boxing Day]] 2004.
===Departure from ''Coronation Street''=== {{Quote box|width=25em|align=right|quote=You have to believe you can have a life after a soap.|source=Jones, in an interview with ''[[The Observer]]''<ref name="Lamont">{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/culture/2011/jul/17/suranne-jones-coronation-street-theatre-lamont|publisher=''[[The Observer]]''|title=Suranne Jones: 'You have to believe there is life after a soap'|first=Tom|last=Lamont|date=2011-07-17|accessdate=2011-07-17}}</ref>}}
Jones stated that upon her departure from ''Coronation Street'', she received numerous offers to appear in [[reality TV]] programmes, which she declined, quipping: "lots of money to go off and [[I'm a Celebrity... Get Me Out of Here!|eat a crocodile's knob]], or whatever".<ref name="Lamont"/> Ignoring reality TV offers, in Autumn 2005, Jones starred in an [[ITV]]'s detective drama series ''[[Vincent (TV series)|Vincent]]'',<ref name="DS Vincent">{{cite news |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a18167/ex-corrie-star-in-new-drama.html|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|title=Ex-'Corrie' star in new drama|first=Daniel|last=Saney|date=2005-01-07|accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref> with [[Ray Winstone]] in the title role; this was Jones' first television role since leaving ''Coronation Street'' the previous year. In the same year she starred on the [[West End theatre|West End]] stage in ''[[A Few Good Men (play)|A Few Good Men]]'' opposite [[Rob Lowe]] and [[John Barrowman]], which earnt her the [[Theatregoers' Choice Award]] for Best Supporting Actress.<ref name="Bio">{{cite news |url=http://www.cft.org.uk/cft-productions_talents.asp?tid=1133|publisher=Chichester Festival Theatre|title=Suranne Jones|first=|last=|date= |accessdate=2011-06-16}}</ref> She also appeared in the musical special ''Celebrate Oliver!'' which was screened on [[BBC1]]. In 2006, she starred as [[Snow White]] in the pantomime Snow White and the Seven Dwarves at the [[Manchester Opera House]] alongside [[Justin Moorhouse]] and fellow ''Coronation Street'' actor [[John Savident]]. She also appeared in [[Kay Mellor]]'s ''[[Strictly Confidential (TV series)|Strictly Confidential]]'' in which she played a [[bisexual]] sex therapist.<ref name="Strictly Confidential">{{cite news |url=http://www.people.co.uk/archive/other/2006/11/12/i-m-open-minded-girl-but-having-sex-on-the-screen-with-men-and-women-wasn-t-easy-93463-18083520/|publisher=People.co.uk|title=I'm an open-minded girl but having sex on the screen with men and women wasn't easy|first=Jon|last=Wise|date=2006-11-12 |accessdate=2011-06-16}}</ref>
On [[New Year's Day]] 2007, Jones starred in a Yorkshire and London based [[black comedy]], ''[[Dead Clever]]'' with [[Helen Baxendale]] and [[Dean Lennox Kelly]] on ITV1. In autumn 2007, Jones undertook a national tour in the stage run of the film ''[[Terms of Endearment]]'', where she played Emma, opposite [[Linda Gray]] and [[John Bowe (actor)|John Bowe]].<ref name="ToE">{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/northyorkshire/content/articles/2007/08/30/review_terms_of_endearment_feature.shtml |title=Review: Terms of Endearment|date=2007-08-30|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=2011-06-16}}</ref> In 2008 she played Martha, one of the female leads, in the ITV medical series ''[[Harley Street (TV series)|Harley Street]]'', though the programme's tepid critical reception, combined with poor viewer ratings signalled the end of the programme after its first series.<ref name="Harley Street">{{cite news |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a205977/suranne-reflects-on-harley-st-failure.html|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|title=Suranne reflects on 'Harley St' failure|first=Daniel|last=Kilkelly|date=2010-03-10 |accessdate=2011-08-27}}</ref>
In January 2009, she appeared in ''[[Unforgiven (TV series)|Unforgiven]]'', a three-part drama on [[ITV1]], where she plays Ruth Slater, a woman released from prison after serving a 15-year prison sentence for the murder of two policemen.<ref name="itv-unforgiven">{{cite news |url= http://www.itv.com/Drama/contemporary/Unforgiven/default.html|title=Unforgiven|date=January 2009|publisher=[[itv.com]]|accessdate=2009-01-21}}</ref> Naturally brown-haired, Jones dyed her hair "tobacco yellow" with "big roots";<ref name="Rebecca Thomas">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7823134.stm|publisher=[[BBC]]|title=Talking Shop: Suranne Jones|first=Rebecca|last=Thomas|date=2009-01-12|accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref> Jones joked that whilst not filming she "really should have worn a wig".<ref name="Rebecca Thomas"/> Additionally, the character of Ruth wore no make-up throughout, with Jones stating she was left feeling "quite exposed", but nonetheless saying "Ruth wouldn't have worn any make-up, I don't think".<ref name="Rebecca Thomas"/> Jones received favourable reviews for her portrayal, with Brian Viner of ''[[The Independent]]'' writing: "a stunning performance, the stuff of [[Bafta]] nominations if ever I saw it. Heck, on the back of it she might even get propelled into the movies, and bring a bit of North Country sense to the [[Golden Globes]]".<ref name="Viner">{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/reviews/last-nights-television-unforgiven-itv1-million-dollar-traders-bbc2-1331682.html|publisher=''[[The Independent]]''|title=Last Night's Television -Unforgiven, ITV1; Million Dollar Traders, BBC2 |first=Brian|last=Viner|date=2009-01-13|accessdate=2011-06-15}}</ref> Viner summarised his review of ''Unforgiven'' by stating, "Five stars all round, and six for Jones".<ref name="Viner"/> Suranne later stated, "I loved that role. They don't come along that often. It was seen by the [[broadsheet]]s as well as the [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|tabloid]]s. It gave me a little bit of credibility, I suppose".<ref name="Independent"/>
Later in the year, in November, she played the role of the [[Mona Lisa]] in the two-part episode "[[Mona Lisa's Revenge]]" in ''[[The Sarah Jane Adventures]]''. In December, Jones starred in the [[Royal Exchange, Manchester|Manchester Royal Exchange]]'s production of ''[[Blithe Spirit (play)|Blithe Spirit]]'', by [[NoÃ«l Coward]], which ran until late January 2010.<ref name="Blithe Spirit">{{cite news |url=http://www.citylife.co.uk/news_and_reviews/reviews/10017492_excellent_cast_makes_blithe_spirit_sparkle |publisher=CityLife.co.uk |title= Excellent cast makes Blithe Spirit sparkle|first=Carmel|last=Thomason|date=2009-12-16|accessdate=2011-06-16}}</ref> Jones was nominated for the Times Breakthrough Award at the 2010 [[South Bank Show|South Bank Show Awards]], the last ever ceremony, but lost to [[David Blandy]].<ref name="South Bank">{{cite news |url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/newsstory.php/27049/donmar-warehouse-scoops-south-bank-show-award|publisher=TheStage.co.uk |title=Donmar Warehouse scoops South Bank Show Award|first=Matthew|last=Hemley|date=2010-01-26|accessdate=2011-06-16}}</ref> When discussing her nomination she said, "You do question 'What am I breaking through?' Am I breaking through the perception of people who just thought I was a screaming [[banshee]] in ''Coronation Street''? Is it that I've worked hard and I've got better? Is it that now it's alright to say that I'm alright? I don't know what I was breaking through, but I knew that it was nice to feel included and patted on the back for a lot of hard work".<ref name="Top Girls interview">{{cite news |url=http://www.officiallondontheatre.co.uk/news/latest/view/item117247/Suranne%20Jones/|publisher=Official London Theatre |title=The Big Interview: Suranne Jones |first=Matthew|last=Amer|date=2011-08-17|accessdate=2011-08-30}}</ref> In March 2010 Jones starred in ''[[Five_Days#Series_two|Five Days]]'', a non-connected sequel to the [[Five_Days#Series_one|2007 series of the same name]], as the female lead DC Laurie Franklin. Later in the year she starred as Sarah in ''[[Single Father (TV drama)|Single Father]]'' on BBC1, a character who falls in love with a widower, Dave ([[David Tennant]]), who was married to her best friend before her death.
On 14 May 2011 she played the central character of Idris in the ''[[Doctor Who]]'' episode "[[The Doctor's Wife (Doctor Who)|The Doctor's Wife]]".<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/doctorwho/dw/news/bulletin_100923_01/Surrane_Jones_confirmed_for_2011 Suranne Jones confirmed for 2011] - 23rd Sep 2010 - BBC</ref> Jones was cast due to writer [[Neil Gaiman]] wanting an actress, in the words of Jones, who is "odd; beautiful but strange looking, and quite funny" to play the role of Idris.<ref name="cultbox">{{cite web |url=http://www.cultbox.co.uk/interviews/exclusives/1025-suranne-jones-doctor-who-interview |title=Suranne Jones ('Doctor Who') interview |first=Will |last=Martin |date=14 May 2011 |accessdate=20 May 2011 |work=Cult Box}}</ref> Dan Martin, reviewer for ''[[The Guardian]]'', noted that "Suranne Jones arguably sets the standard by which all guest stars must now be judged here [...] Jones was electrifying throughout".<ref name="guardian">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2011/may/14/doctor-who-doctors-wife-gaiman|title=Doctor Who: The Doctor's Wife â Series 32, episode 4|last=Martin|first=Dan|date=14 May 2010|work=[[The Guardian]]|language=[[English language|English]]|accessdate=15 May 2011|location=London}}</ref> Later, Jones played DC Rachel Bailey in ITV's new six-part detective series, ''[[Scott & Bailey]]'', alongside [[Lesley Sharp]], who plays DC Janet Scott.<ref>http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1843678/</ref> The series is based upon an original idea by Jones and [[Sally Lindsay]], a former ''Coronation Street'' co-star.<ref name="S&B">{{cite web |url=http://www.itv.com/presscentre/presspacks/scottandbaileypresspack/default.html|title=''Scott and Bailey'' press pack |first=|last= |date=2011-05-16|accessdate=2011-06-15 |work=ITV}}</ref> In July, Jones starred as Marlene, a career-woman living in [[Margaret Thatcher|Thatcher]]'s Britain, in the [[Minerva Theatre, Chichester|Minerva Theatre]]'s production of ''[[Top Girls]]'' by [[Caryl Churchill]] in [[Chichester]]. Michael Billington, reviewer for ''The Guardian'', remarked that "Suranne Jones captures excellently the hidden regrets of the go-getting Marlene".<ref name="Top Girls">{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/stage/2011/jul/04/top-girls-review|title=Top Girls - review |first=Michael|last=Billington |date=2011-07-04|accessdate=2011-07-06 |work=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref> The production was later transferred to the [[West End theatre|West End]]'s [[Trafalgar Studios]].<ref name="West End">{{cite news |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/theatre/review-23978889-top-girls-trafalgar-studios---review.do|title=Top Girls, Trafalgar Studios - review |first=Fiona|last=Mountford |date=2011-08-17|accessdate=2011-08-26 |work=[[Evening Standard]]}}</ref>
In August it was announced that Jones would star alongside [[John Hannah (actor)|John Hannah]] in a spoof detective drama written by [[Charlie Brooker]] and [[Daniel Maier]] called ''A Touch of Cloth''.<ref name="A Touch of Cloth">{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/2011/aug/26/charlie-brooker-spoof-crime-drama-sky1|title=Charlie Brooker pens spoof crime drama for Sky1 |first=John|last=Plunkett |date=2011-08-26|accessdate=2011-08-26 |work=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref> The programme, which as of yet does not have an air date, is set to be broadcast on [[Sky1]].<ref name="A Touch of Cloth"/> Jones plays DC Anne Oldman,<ref name="A Touch of Cloth 2">{{cite news |url=http://www.whatsontv.co.uk/drama/tv-news/news/suranne-and-john-hannah-to-star-in-detective-spoof/13778|title=Suranne and John Hannah to star in detective spoof |first=|last=|date=2011-08-26|accessdate=2011-08-26 |work=[[What's on TV]]}}</ref> the "plucky, no-nonsense sidekick" of DCI Jack Cloth (John Hannah).<ref name="A Touch of Cloth"/>
==Personal life== Jones remains in Manchester and lives in a "150-year-old cottage",<ref name="Daily Mail"/> though stated in 2010 she was searching for a flat in London too, due to her career requiring that she spend most of the week there.<ref name="Daily Mail"/> She lives with her [[Jack Russell Terrier]], Baxter. Whilst playing Karen McDonald in ''Coronation Street'', Jones became engaged to Jim Phelan, an IT consultant, however, the couple separated.<ref name="Billen"/>
Jones has been involved with various charitable organisations; as a teenager, Jones' mother Jenny was diagnosed with [[breast cancer]], with Jones saying "at the time we did a breast cancer campaign together. I still do a lot of charity runs".<ref name="Daily Mail"/> Jones also has worked with [[Christian Aid]], travelling to [[Sierra Leone]] and the [[Democratic Republic of Congo]] (the latter accompanied by Sally Lindsay), helping with projects concerning [[HIV]], [[women's rights]] and [[child soldiers]].<ref name="CA">{{cite web |url=http://www.christianaid.org.uk/aboutus/celebrity-supporters/suranne-jones.aspx|title=Celebrity Supporters - Suranne Jones |first=|last= |date=|accessdate=2011-06-17 |work=[[Christian Aid]]}}</ref>
